awd_titl_txt: Coherent Structures and Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Coherent structures, such as the elliptical or spiral galaxies in the universe, or large scale vortex structures in the atmosphere and ocean, or surface water waves, are observed in many natural phenomena. This research is aimed at understanding the formation and evolution of such coherent structures (that in some cases are amenable to mathematical analysis). A first question is their stability, that is, whether they persist even if they experience perturbations. Understanding the mechanisms of instability and stability is fundamental for many applications. An example is the importance in plasma physics and engineering of understanding mechanisms of instability, to enable design of devices able to contain plasma long enough for practical fusion energy production. Another topic is to understand the dynamical roles of coherent structures. For example, how do we explain the appearance of the large-scale structures observed in the atmosphere and oceans? What is the mechanism for an initially unstructured state to approach a final coherent state? Such problems are far from being thoroughly understood. Methods of mathematical analysis are the primary tools employed in this investigation. The rigorous mathematics makes it feasible to do stable numerical computations and to better understand the phenomena found in numerical and experimental studies.

One focus of the project is the stability problem for Hamiltonian partial differential equations with energy functional of infinite Morse index. They include gravity water waves (and many long wave models), nonlinear Dirac equations, ion acoustic wave equations, and Vlasov models for collisionless plasmas. In contrast to the cases with energy functional of finite Morse index, to date there are very few general tools for stability problems with infinite Morse index. Several models, including the regularized Boussinesq equation and two-dimensional Euler equation, will be studied, with the goal to develop some general tools for stability problems of infinite Morse index. Another focus of the project is the metastability of coherent structures and the persistence of invariant structures under small dissipation. They include the metastability of quasi-stationary flows of the two-dimensional Navier-Stokes equation with small viscosity, and the inviscid limit of invariant manifolds of Navier-Stokes equations. Hamiltonian and geometric structures of the fluid equations will be explored in these investigations.

por.por_cntn:
During 2017-2021, the PI obtained the following results.

1. With Zeng, we developed a general framework of linear Hamiltonian PDEs to study stability problems for many conservative PDE models including long wave models for water waves, Euler equation for ideal fluids, and Gross-Pitaevskii equation for superfludis. The results obtained include: a generalized instability index formula, exponential trichotomy estimates for the linearized semigroup and a sharp criterion for structural stability of Hamiltonian PDEs. 

2. With Jin and Zeng, we developed a general approach of constructing invariant (stable, unstable and center) manifolds near unstable coherent states (traveling waves, stabnding waves etc.) for a large class of dispersive wave models including generalized KDV equation and Gross-Pitaevskii equation. This gave a complete description of local dynamcics near unstable coherent states. 

3. With C. Zeng, we consider stability of non-rotating gaseous stars modeled by the Euler-Poisson system. Under general assumptions on the equation of states, we proved a turning point principle (TPP) that the stability of the stars is entirely determined by the mass-radius curve parameterized by the center density. In particular, the stability can only change at extrema (i.e. local maximum or minimum points) of the total mass. Moreover, we get a precise counting of unstable modes and exponential trichotomy estimates for the linearized Euler-Poisson system. To prove these results, we develop a general framework of separable Hamiltonian PDEs. The general approach is flexible and can be used for many other problems.

4. With M. Hadzic, we proved similar turning point principle for nontotating relativistic stars (e.g. neutraon stars) modeled by Euler-Einstein equations.

5. With Hadzic and Rein, we studied the stability of relativisitc galaxies modeled by Vlasov-Einstein equations. We prove their linear instability when the central redshift is sufficiently large, i.e., when they are strongly relativistic. Our work confirms the scenario of dynamic instability proposed in the 1960s by Zel'dovich and Podurets.

6. With Yucong Wang, we studied the stability of rotating stars under axisymmetric perturbations. When the angular velocity satisfies the Rayleigh stability condition, we obtained a sharp stability criterion. In particular, the rotation is shown to have a stabilizing effect. By using this criterion, we showed that for the slow rotating stars with fixed angular velocity, the turning point principle is not true. That is, the exchange of stability does not happen at the extrema points of the total mass for the family of rotating stars parametrized by the center density. In contrast, we showed that for slow rotating stars with fixed angular momentum distribution, the turning point principle is true. When the angular velocity does not satisfy the Rayleigh condition, we proved that linear instability always occur due to the unstable essential spectrum. 

7. We consider linear stability of steady states of 1(1/2) and 3D Vlasov-Maxwell systems for collisionless plasmas. The linearized systems can be written as separable Hamiltonian systems with constraints. By using the general theory for separable Hamiltonian systems, we recover the sharp linear stability criteria obtained previously by different approaches. Moreover, we obtain the exponential trichotomy estimates for the linearized Vlasov-Maxwell systems in both relativistic and nonrelativistic cases.

8. With Hao Zho and Shasha Liao, we studied the stability of Stuart vortices which are important in studying the mixing layers of fluids. We proved stability for perturbations of minimal period and instability for perturbations of multiple periods. This verified the conjecture in the fluid literature since 1960s. 

9. With Mingwen Fei, Chen Gao and Tao Tao, we study the steady Navier-Stokes equations in two dimensional annulus with rotating boundaries. By constructing higher order approximate solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations and establishing the L1 estimate for the error equation, we justify the validity of the Prandtl boundary layer expansions in this setting. In particular, we prove that there is a continuous family of solutions of the steady Navier-Stokes equation when the viscosity is suciently small. Our result partially verify the Prandtl-Batchelor Theorem for steady Navier-Stokes equations in the inviscid limit. 

10. With Zhifei Zhang, Hao Zhu and Dongyi Wei, we study the number of traveling wave families near a shear flow under the influence of Coriolis force, where the traveling speeds lie outside the range of the shear. Under general assumptions, we proved that the number of traveling wave families change from finite to infinite when the Rossby number crosses a critical value. This sudden change of the number of traveling wave families indicates that nonlinear dynamics around the shear flow is much richer than the non-rotating case, where no such traveling wave solutions.
